page.title: 05The Stather
page.content: The Stather nestles below Burton on the banks of the Trent.'Stather' indicates the Danish connection for it is Old Norse meaning 'landing place on a river.'There was a ferry service across the river until 1924.This service operated 16 hours a day, seven days a week but could be called out in an emergency during the night because it was a King's Ferry, a main road. Today this is remembered in the King's Ferry Wharf.There was also a packet steamer ferry service which linked Burton with Gainsborough and Hull. During the 2nd World War the Stather was used by soldiers to practise for the Normandy landing.For years the Stather was renowned for boat building.In 1985 it is a thriving wharf bringing trade and employment but the large lorries cause problems in the narrow streets.
